Name: Pattern Recognition - PE
Text: Looking at the temporal profile, the first thing that stands out is the R to P step with a very low standard deviation. That suggests a very consistent time, which might indicate automation or a strict policy.

Name: Hypothesis Generation - IND
Text: Maybe the approval is happening too quickly, bypassing necessary checks.

Name: Pattern Recognition - PE
Text: Next, P to N has a long average time with a high standard deviation. This could mean either there are delays or some cases are getting processed much faster, possibly due to automated notifications after approval.

Name: Hypothesis Generation - IND
Text: For P to N, perhaps resource issues or system delays are causing the inconsistency.

Name: Pattern Recognition - PE
Text: Then, A to C is very quick. Maybe claims are being closed without proper evaluation, which could be a sign of errors or fraud.

Name: Hypothesis Generation - NE
Text: A to C might involve skipping steps, leading to a lack of thorough claim handling and potentially causing errors or fraudulent activity.

Name: Pattern Recognition - PE
Text: Similarly, E to N is too fast, suggesting notifications are sent immediately after evaluation without any further checks.

Name: Hypothesis Generation - IND
Text: E to N could indicate automation without proper oversight or skipping intermediate validation steps.

Name: Validation - PE
Text: Proposing SQL queries to calculate time differences between steps and identify claims outside expected ranges.

Name: Deductive Reasoning - PE
Text: Using the database schema to identify patterns or adjuster/region-specific anomalies that may explain the temporal inconsistencies.
